div1.p: Carter critiques [Emmett Vaughan's] article on yellow fever.

div1.head: Memorandum [on Emmett Vaughan article], [by Henry Rose Carter], [May, 1923]

list.head: Memorandum.
list.item:
1) Page I: I have seen these so-called “fulminant” cases of yellow
fever (“accesiones perniciosas”) only in company with many others of
less severity: Have never seen them when there need be a question of
diagnosis.
2) Page 2: Is this proven?

3) Page 3: I think he means infections “closely resembling it,”
rather than “closely allied.”

4) Page 4: Epigastric tenderness is not a marked symptom in the
beginning of yellow fever--see Page 10--where it is placed correctly
later--3rd. day usually.

5) Page 4: This description of the facies is not very good--a dusky
flush of passive congestion succeeds the acute congestion. See next
paragraph.

6) Page 5: Mouth temperatures are intended and this is correct.
The high temperatures recorded in Guayaquil in Noguchi's papers were,
Pareja tells me, rectal.

6') Page 6: It is hardly fair to consider this so-called “typhoid
stage” yellow fever, though it does occur in cases that ought to have
died and did't.

7) Page 6: Faget's sign is not well described. His (Faget's) own
formulation of it is better. He only claims it to exist for 3 days.

8) Page 8: Might add to this paragraph “and is liable to occur
early in stage of active congestion.”

9) Page 9: Is not insomnia well nigh invariable unless hypnotics
are taken?

10) Page 9: It is usual for coma to preceed death and for death to
occur in convulsions.
convulsions.
11) Page 9: This is absolutely correct and I am glad he noted it.

12) Page 10: I don't think there is any red in the early streaks
of black-vomit, but I suppose it is a matter of opinion and color sense.

13) Page 10: This is correct and usually on the 3rd. day. (See
remark 4) Page 4).

14) Page 11: Some of these fulminant cases (“accesiones perniciosas”)
do not vomit at all: none that I have seen die within 24 hours vomited
blood, but I have only seen 3 that did. I suspect those that vomited
were “walking cases” and sick longer than was thought. Would make no
change, however, as he probably has seen such.

item.p:
15) Page 11: Might have noted the general appearance of the body:
bloodlessness of incision etc.

The most characteristic histologic change in the liver is the
“midzonal necrosis” of da Rocha Lima, which I think should be mentioned.

list.item:
16) Page 12: I suppose he means a colon after Malaria Fever. If
so delete “and.” If not, re-write.

17) Page 12: “suspicion seems justifiable.” Paragraph is rather
mild.

18) Page 13: I don't know what this means. Macroscopic blood in
the urine in yellow fever must be extremely rare. I have never seen it,
nor has Guiteras nor Dutroleau.
19) Page 14: I don't think so. (See # 18) ).

20) Page 14: This is all true, but the black water is, in my mind,
the differential. If this occurs in yellow fever the case must be a ful-
minant one and the symptoms so well marked that diagnosis should be easy.

21) Page 15: Leucopenia quite generally occurs in mild cases of
yellow fever, especially in the beginning--the kind of cases it is most
difficult to differentiate and at the time when it is most important to
to
3
differentiate them from dengue. I don't think this differential can be
depended on.
22) Page 15: Delete.

23) Page 17: I doubt if one man ever sees enough cases of this dis-
ease to make a percentage of its accidents. I have not heard of confu-
sion between it an yellow fever, except in Santiago de Cuba in 1899, when
yellow fever was intentionally misreported.
24) Page 18: This might, and I think should, be more elaborated.

25) Page 20: Would it be well to mention the gain in time by the
use of the serum intravenously?
